::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(papaja)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Loading required package: tinylabels
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Simulated data
CBT <- c(23, 19, 21, 22, 20, 24, 25, 18, 22, 23)
Placebo <- c(30, 28, 27, 29, 31, 32, 33, 30, 29, 28)

# Combine into a data frame
data <- data.frame(
  group = factor(rep(c("CBT", "Placebo"), each = 10)),
  anxiety = c(CBT, Placebo)
)


# Example: t-test in APA format
t_test_results <- t.test(anxiety ~ group, data = data)

# Use apa_print to format the output
apa_output <- apa_print(t_test_results)
print(apa_output)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
$estimate
[1] "$\\Delta M = -8.00$, 95\\% CI $[-9.94, -6.06]$"

$statistic
[1] "$t(17.56) = -8.69$, $p < .001$"

$full_result
[1] "$\\Delta M = -8.00$, 95\\% CI $[-9.94, -6.06]$, $t(17.56) = -8.69$, $p < .001$"

$table
A data.frame with 5 labelled columns:

  estimate       conf.int statistic    df p.value
1    -8.00 [-9.94, -6.06]     -8.69 17.56  < .001

estimate : $\\Delta M$ 
conf.int : 95\\% CI 
statistic: $t$ 
df       : $\\mathit{df}$ 
p.value  : $p$ 
attr(,"class")
[1] "apa_results" "list"       
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(report)

# Example: t-test in APA format
t_test_results <- t.test(anxiety ~ group, data = data)

# Generate the report
report_output <- report(t_test_results)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Unable to retrieve data from htest object.
  Returning an approximate effect size using t_to_d().
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
print(report_output)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Effect sizes were labelled following Cohen's (1988) recommendations.

The Welch Two Sample t-test testing the difference of anxiety by group (mean in
group CBT = 21.70, mean in group Placebo = 29.70) suggests that the effect is
negative, statistically significant, and large (difference = -8.00, 95% CI
[-9.94, -6.06], t(17.56) = -8.69, p < .001; Cohen's d = -4.15, 95% CI [-5.78,
-2.48])
```
